title: Bioinformatics Module | Bioinformatics and Drug Design
text:
This 7-week module introduces bioinformatics concepts and tools relevant for pharmaceutical sciences. Students will gain hands-on experience with public databases and online tools to retrieve, analyse, and interpret genomic, proteomic, and transcriptomic data.
Format:
- 1 hour theoretical lecture
- 2 hours computer-based theoreticalâ€“practical class
- 1 class per week
Target audience: Pharmacy students with basic knowledge in molecular biology and genetics.
Assessment:

Final short video report: characterisation of a gene/protein using bioinformatics tools.

5 minutes max;
Groups of 2 students;
Final presentation and discussion of the video report.

title: Bioinformatics Module | Bioinformatics and Drug Design
text:
This 7-week module introduces bioinformatics concepts and tools relevant for pharmaceutical sciences. Students will gain hands-on experience with public databases and online tools to retrieve, analyse, and interpret genomic, proteomic, and transcriptomic data.
Format:
- 1 hour theoretical lecture
- 2 hours computer-based theoreticalâ€“practical class
- 1 class per week
Target audience: Pharmacy students with basic knowledge in molecular biology and genetics.
Assessment:

Final short video report: characterisation of a gene/protein using bioinformatics tools.

5 minutes max;
Groups of 2 students;
Final presentation and discussion of the video report.

title: Bioinformatics Module | Bioinformatics and Drug Design
text:
Weekly Schedule

Week 1 â€“ Introduction to Bioinformatics and Biological Databases
Lecture Topics:

Definition and scope of bioinformatics.
Bioinformatics in drug discovery.
Overview of biological data types.
Introduction to primary and secondary databases.

Practical Activities:

Explore NCBI, EMBL-EBI, and Ensembl.
Retrieve gene and protein sequences (e.g.Â TP53).
Use Ensembl Genome Browser to view gene structure.




Week 2 â€“ Protein-Coding Genes and Genome Annotation
Lecture Topics:

Gene structure, transcripts, exons, splice variants.
Functional annotation and reference genomes.
UniProt and genome browsers.

Practical Activities:

Use UCSC Genome Browser and Ensembl.
Inspect exon-intron structure, SNPs, and isoforms.
Retrieve protein information from UniProt.




Week 3 â€“ Sequence Alignment and Similarity Searches
Lecture Topics:

Sequence alignment: global vs.Â local.
BLAST algorithm, scoring, E-value.
Orthology and paralogy.

Practical Activities:

Perform BLAST searches via NCBI.
Analyse alignment outputs and E-values.
Multiple sequence alignment with Clustal Omega.




Week 4 â€“ Gene and Protein Function Annotation
Lecture Topics:

Gene Ontology (GO): biological process, molecular function, cellular component.
Functional annotation via InterPro, Pfam, QuickGO.

Practical Activities:

Annotate protein domains using InterPro and Pfam.
Retrieve and explore GO terms with QuickGO and AmiGO.
Analyse UniProt GO annotations.




Week 5 â€“ Pathways and Systems Biology Resources
Lecture Topics:

Pathways in biology and pharmacology.
Databases: KEGG, Reactome, STRING.
Integrating pathway data with gene/protein functions.

Practical Activities:

Use KEGG Pathway Browser to explore drug metabolism.
Map gene lists to pathways.
Explore proteinâ€“protein interaction networks with STRING.




Week 6 â€“ Functional Genomics and Expression Data
Lecture Topics:

Overview of omics: microarray vs.Â RNA-seq.
Data repositories: GEO, ArrayExpress.
Tissue-specific and disease-specific expression.

Practical Activities:

Retrieve datasets from GEO and ArrayExpress.
Explore expression profiles using Expression Atlas.
Use Human Protein Atlas for tissue expression data.




Week 7 â€“ Integration and Case Study
Lecture Topics:

Integration of sequence, function, and expression data.
Use of bioinformatics in drug target discovery.
Ethical and legal aspects of biomedical data reuse.

Practical Activities:

Case study: integrated analysis of a drug target gene (e.g.Â EGFR or BRCA1).
Combine sequence, function, expression, and pathway information.
Produce a structured summary of findings.
